title: Vasicek model
text:
In <a href="Mathematical%20finance">finance</a>, the Vasicek model is a <a href="mathematical%20model">mathematical model</a> describing the evolution of <a href="interest%20rate">interest rate</a>s. It is a type of one-factor <a href="short-rate%20model">short-rate model</a> as it describes interest rate movements as driven by only one source of <a href="market%20risk">market risk</a>. The model can be used in the valuation of <a href="interest%20rate%20derivative">interest rate derivative</a>s, and has also been adapted for credit markets. It was introduced in 1977 by <a href="Old%C5%99ich%20Va%C5%A1%C3%AD%C4%8Dek">Oldřich Vašíček</a>, and can be also seen as a <a href="stochastic%20investment%20model">stochastic investment model</a>.

This model is an <a href="Ornstein%E2%80%93Uhlenbeck%20process">Ornstein–Uhlenbeck stochastic process</a>. Making the long term mean stochastic to another SDE is a simplified version of the cointelation SDE.
Discussion.
Vasicek's model was the first one to capture <a href="Mean%20reversion%20%28finance%29">mean reversion</a>, an essential characteristic of the interest rate that sets it apart from other financial prices. Thus, as opposed to <a href="common%20stock">stock</a> prices for instance, interest rates cannot rise indefinitely. This is because at very high levels they would hamper economic activity, prompting a decrease in interest rates. Similarly, interest rates do not usually decrease below 0. As a result, interest rates move in a limited range, showing a tendency to revert to a long run value.
The drift factor formula_25 represents the expected instantaneous change in the interest rate at time "t". The parameter "b" represents the <a href="long-run">long-run</a> <a href="steady%20state">equilibrium</a> value towards which the interest rate reverts. Indeed, in the absence of shocks (formula_26), the interest rate remains constant when "rt = b". The parameter "a", governing the speed of adjustment, needs to be positive to ensure <a href="stability%20theory">stability</a> around the long term value. For example, when "rt" is below "b", the drift term formula_25 becomes positive for positive "a", generating a tendency for the interest rate to move upwards (toward equilibrium).
The main disadvantage is that, under Vasicek's model, it is theoretically possible for the interest rate to become negative, an undesirable feature under pre-crisis assumptions. This shortcoming was fixed in the <a href="Cox%E2%80%93Ingersoll%E2%80%93Ross%20model">Cox–Ingersoll–Ross model</a>, exponential Vasicek model, <a href="Black%E2%80%93Derman%E2%80%93Toy%20model">Black–Derman–Toy model</a> and <a href="Black%E2%80%93Karasinski%20model">Black–Karasinski model</a>, among many others. The Vasicek model was further extended in the <a href="Hull%E2%80%93White%20model">Hull–White model</a>. The Vasicek model is also a canonical example of the <a href="affine%20term%20structure%20model">affine term structure model</a>, along with the <a href="Cox%E2%80%93Ingersoll%E2%80%93Ross%20model">Cox–Ingersoll–Ross model</a>. In recent research both models were used for data partitioning and forecasting.
